description: From Latin inhalare (“to breathe on (breathe in)”), from in (“in, into, on”) + halare (“to breathe”).

examples: Now have client take slower, normal breaths through the nose and notice how the abdomen moves slightly outward with each inhale and then deflates with each exhale.

verbs.description: inhale (third-person singular simple present inhales, present participle inhaling, simple past and past participle inhaled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To draw air into the lungs, through the nose or mouth by action of the diaphragm.
examples: Antonyms: breathe out, outbreathe, exhale, expire (archaic)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To draw air or any form of gas (either in a pure form, or mixed with small particles in form of aerosols/smoke -sometimes stemming from a medicament) into the lungs, through the nose or mouth by action of the diaphragm.
